metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Analyse transformations of energy between kinetic energy, elastic potential energy, gravitational potential energy and energy dissipated to the environment (considered as a combination of heat, sound and deformation of material): kinetic energy at low speeds Ek = ½mv²; elastic potential energy Es = ½kx²; gravitational potential energy Eg = mgΔh

kinetic_energy_formula.name: Kinetic Energy Formula
kinetic_energy_formula.correct: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion, calculated as KE = ½mv². It depends on mass and velocity squared, making it a scalar quantity always positive or zero.

KE = mv².fix: KE = ½mv². The half is essential.
KE = mv².action: Double-check: KE formula has ½ in front.

KE = ½mv.fix: KE = ½mv². That's v², not v.
KE = ½mv.action: Energy depends on v². Double speed = quadruple KE.

KE = mv.action: Momentum is linear in v; KE is quadratic in v.

KE can be negative.error: KE is always positive or zero (scalar).
KE can be negative.fix: v² is always positive. Mass is positive. So KE ≥ 0.
KE can be negative.action: Direction doesn't affect KE; it's energy of motion.

persistent.gap: You don't know the kinetic energy formula correctly.
persistent.action: KE = ½mv². Scalar, always ≥ 0. Unit: joule (J).

ke_velocity_squared.name: KE Proportional to v²
ke_velocity_squared.correct: Kinetic energy is proportional to velocity squared. Doubling velocity quadruples KE; tripling velocity gives 9× KE.

double v means double KE.fix: KE ∝ v². If v doubles, KE = ½m(2v)² = ½m × 4v² = 4 × original KE.

halving v halves KE.fix: v → v/2 means KE → KE/4 (because (½)² = ¼).

KE doesn't depend on v.error: KE strongly depends on v (squared relationship).
KE doesn't depend on v.action: This is why high-speed collisions are so dangerous.

persistent.gap: You don't understand the v² relationship in KE.
persistent.action: KE ∝ v². Double v → 4× KE. Triple v → 9× KE. Square the factor.

gravitational_pe_formula.name: Gravitational PE Formula
gravitational_pe_formula.correct: Gravitational potential energy equals mass × gravitational field strength × height. GPE = mgh. It depends on position (height) in a gravitational field.

GPE = mg.error: Missing height. mg is weight (force), not energy.

GPE = ½mgh.fix: GPE = mgh (not ½mgh). The ½ is in KE and elastic PE.
GPE = ½mgh.action: Different formulas: KE has ½, GPE does not.

GPE = mgh².fix: GPE = mgh. Linear in h, not h².

GPE is always positive.error: GPE depends on reference point; can be negative below it.
GPE is always positive.fix: GPE = 0 at reference. Above: positive. Below: negative.

persistent.gap: You don't know the GPE formula correctly.
persistent.action: GPE = mgh. m = mass, g = 9.8 m/s², h = height above reference.

gpe_reference_point.name: GPE Reference Point
gpe_reference_point.correct: GPE is measured relative to a chosen reference point where GPE = 0. Only changes in GPE (ΔGPE = mgΔh) have physical meaning.

ground is always zero.error: You can choose any reference point.
ground is always zero.fix: Ground is common but not required. Table, floor, any level works.

reference doesn't matter.error: Reference affects GPE values (but not ΔGPE).
reference doesn't matter.fix: Different reference = different GPE values. Same Δh = same ΔGPE.
reference doesn't matter.action: Changes in GPE are absolute; GPE values are relative.

must use sea level.action: Often use lowest point in problem as reference.

can change reference mid-problem.fix: Once chosen, reference must stay fixed.

persistent.gap: You don't understand GPE reference points.
persistent.action: Choose reference where GPE = 0. Keep it consistent. Only ΔGPE matters physically.

elastic_pe_formula.name: Elastic PE Formula
elastic_pe_formula.correct: Elastic potential energy in an ideal spring is Es = ½kx², where k is spring constant and x is compression/extension from natural length.

Es = kx.error: That's Hooke's law for force, not energy.
Es = kx.action: Energy has ½ and x² (area under F-x graph).

Es = ½kx.fix: Es = ½kx². The x² comes from the triangular area.

Es = kx².fix: Es = ½kx². The ½ comes from the triangular graph area.
Es = kx².action: Area of triangle = ½ × base × height = ½ × x × kx = ½kx².

Es depends on mass.error: Elastic PE depends on k and x, not mass.
Es depends on mass.fix: Es = ½kx². No m in this formula.
Es depends on mass.action: Spring stores energy based on stiffness and compression, not attached mass.

persistent.gap: You don't know the elastic PE formula correctly.
persistent.action: Es = ½kx². k = spring constant (N/m), x = compression or extension (m).

hookes_law.name: Hooke's Law
hookes_law.correct: Hooke's law states that spring force is proportional to displacement: F = kx. The spring constant k measures stiffness (N/m). Higher k = stiffer spring.

F = k/x.error: Force is proportional to x, not inversely proportional.
F = k/x.fix: F = kx. More stretch = more force (linear relationship).

k has units of N.error: k has units N/m (force per unit extension).
k has units of N.fix: k = F/x, so units are N/m.
k has units of N.action: Spring constant tells you newtons needed per metre of stretch.

higher k means easier to stretch.error: Higher k means stiffer (harder to stretch).
higher k means easier to stretch.fix: F = kx. Large k needs large F for given x.
higher k means easier to stretch.action: Stiff spring = high k. Soft spring = low k.

applies to all extensions.error: Only for ideal springs within elastic limit.
applies to all extensions.fix: Beyond elastic limit, spring deforms permanently.

persistent.gap: You don't understand Hooke's law correctly.
persistent.action: F = kx. k = spring constant (N/m). Linear relationship for ideal springs.

spring_constant.name: Spring Constant
spring_constant.formula: k = F/x = gradient of F-x graph
spring_constant.correct: The spring constant k is the gradient of a force-extension graph. Higher k means stiffer spring. Units: N/m.

k is area under graph.fix: k = rise/run = F/x = gradient. Area = ½kx² = energy.
k is area under graph.action: Gradient for k, area for energy.

k depends on compression.error: k is constant for ideal spring (hence 'constant').
k depends on compression.fix: k stays same regardless of how much you compress/extend.
k depends on compression.action: Linear graph: same gradient everywhere = constant k.

lower k is stiffer.error: Higher k = stiffer. Lower k = softer.
lower k is stiffer.fix: Stiff spring needs more force per metre: high k.
lower k is stiffer.action: Car suspension: high k. Slinky: low k.

units are N·m.action: N·m is torque or energy. N/m is spring constant.

persistent.gap: You don't understand spring constant correctly.
persistent.action: k = F/x = gradient of F-x graph. Units: N/m. Higher k = stiffer spring.

conservation_of_energy.name: Conservation of Energy
conservation_of_energy.correct: In a closed system with no energy dissipation, total mechanical energy is conserved: KE + GPE + Es = constant. Energy transforms between forms but total stays same.

energy is created.error: Energy cannot be created or destroyed.
energy is created.fix: Energy transforms between forms; total stays constant.
energy is created.action: Falling ball: GPE → KE. Energy not created, just transformed.

only KE is conserved.error: Total energy is conserved, not just KE.
only KE is conserved.fix: KE can change; it transforms to/from other forms.
only KE is conserved.action: Rising ball: KE → GPE. KE decreases but total constant.

applies to open systems.fix: Open systems can gain/lose energy to surroundings.

potential energy doesn't count.error: PE is part of total mechanical energy.
potential energy doesn't count.action: Include all energy forms in the system.

persistent.gap: You don't understand conservation of energy.
persistent.action: Closed system: E_total = KE + GPE + Es = constant. Energy transforms, not created/destroyed.

energy_transformations.name: Energy Transformation Analysis
energy_transformations.formula: KE_i + GPE_i + Es_i = KE_f + GPE_f + Es_f
energy_transformations.correct: Energy transformations: falling converts GPE→KE; rising converts KE→GPE; compressing spring converts KE→Es; releasing spring converts Es→KE.

energy disappears.error: Energy transforms to other forms, not disappears.
energy disappears.fix: Track where energy goes: KE ↔ GPE ↔ Es.
energy disappears.action: If KE decreases, some PE must increase (or dissipation).

GPE only at top.error: GPE exists at any height above reference.
GPE only at top.fix: GPE = mgh at any height h.
GPE only at top.action: GPE is maximum at highest point, but exists at all heights.

KE only when moving fast.error: Any motion has KE, even slow motion.
KE only when moving fast.action: Slow = small KE. Fast = large KE. Stationary = zero KE.

transformations are instantaneous.fix: As height changes, GPE and KE continuously change.
transformations are instantaneous.action: Energy flows between forms throughout the motion.

persistent.action: Track energy: falling (GPE→KE), rising (KE→GPE), spring compress (KE→Es), spring release (Es→KE).

energy_dissipation.name: Energy Dissipation
energy_dissipation.correct: In real systems, mechanical energy is dissipated to the environment as heat, sound, and material deformation. This is not energy destruction—it transforms to less useful forms.

energy is destroyed.error: Energy is conserved; it transforms to other forms.
energy is destroyed.action: Total energy constant; mechanical energy decreases.

only heat matters.error: Sound and deformation also receive energy.
only heat matters.action: Car crash: crumpling (deformation), bang (sound), hot metal (heat).

dissipation only in collisions.error: Friction, air resistance also dissipate energy.
dissipation only in collisions.action: Sliding friction → heat. Air resistance → heat.

dissipated energy is recoverable.error: Dissipated energy is 'lost' to useful work.
dissipated energy is recoverable.fix: Heat spreads out; very hard to recover.
dissipated energy is recoverable.action: This is why perpetual motion is impossible.

persistent.action: Dissipation: mechanical energy → heat + sound + deformation. Energy conserved but less useful.

elastic_inelastic_collisions_energy.name: Elastic vs Inelastic (Energy)
elastic_inelastic_collisions_energy.formula: Elastic: KE conserved. Inelastic: KE not conserved
elastic_inelastic_collisions_energy.correct: In elastic collisions, kinetic energy is conserved. In inelastic collisions, some KE is dissipated. Momentum is conserved in both types.

elastic means bouncy.error: Elastic means KE conserved, not just bouncy.
elastic means bouncy.action: Bouncy but losing energy = still inelastic.

inelastic means they stick.fix: Inelastic = any KE loss. Perfectly inelastic = stick together.
inelastic means they stick.action: Most collisions are inelastic but objects don't stick.

momentum not conserved in inelastic.error: Momentum always conserved in isolated systems.
momentum not conserved in inelastic.fix: Momentum conserved in BOTH elastic and inelastic.
momentum not conserved in inelastic.action: KE is what differs: conserved (elastic) vs not (inelastic).

all real collisions are elastic.fix: Real collisions lose KE to heat, sound, deformation.
all real collisions are elastic.action: Elastic collisions are rare (gas molecules, subatomic).

persistent.gap: You confuse elastic and inelastic collision energy.
persistent.action: Elastic: KE conserved. Inelastic: KE not conserved. Momentum conserved in both.

area_under_force_distance.name: Area Under Force-Distance Graph
area_under_force_distance.formula: Work = Area under F-s graph; Energy = Area under F-x graph
area_under_force_distance.correct: The area under a force-distance graph gives work done or energy stored. For springs, area under F-x graph = elastic PE = ½kx².

gradient gives energy.error: Gradient of F-x graph gives k (spring constant).
gradient gives energy.action: For energy: calculate area. For k: calculate gradient.

area gives force.error: Area gives energy (J). Height gives force (N).
area gives force.fix: Area = N × m = J (energy). Read force from y-axis.

only for rectangles.error: Works for any shape: triangle for springs.
only for rectangles.fix: Linear F-x graph → triangle → area = ½ × base × height.

doesn't apply to GPE.error: GPE can also be found from force-distance graph.
doesn't apply to GPE.fix: Area under gravitational force-distance graph = ΔGPE.

persistent.gap: You don't understand area under force-distance graphs.
persistent.action: Area under F-s graph = work/energy. For springs: triangular area = ½kx².

vertical_spring_systems.name: Vertical Spring-Mass Systems
vertical_spring_systems.correct: In vertical spring systems, energy transforms between GPE, KE, and elastic PE. At equilibrium, mg = kx. Maximum speed occurs at equilibrium position.

only two energies involved.error: All three: GPE, KE, and Es.
only two energies involved.fix: Vertical spring: height changes (GPE), speed changes (KE), spring stretches (Es).
only two energies involved.action: Must track all three energy forms.

max speed at top or bottom.fix: At equilibrium: net force = 0, acceleration = 0, but velocity maximum.
max speed at top or bottom.action: Equilibrium ≠ stationary. Object is moving fastest there.

equilibrium means rest.error: Equilibrium means net force = 0, not zero velocity.
equilibrium means rest.fix: At equilibrium: F_net = 0 but object moving (inertia).
equilibrium means rest.action: Mass oscillates through equilibrium at maximum speed.

spring always compressed.error: Hanging spring is extended; standing spring is compressed.
spring always compressed.fix: Hanging: mass pulls down, spring extends. Standing: mass pushes down, spring compresses.
spring always compressed.action: Check whether spring stretches or squashes.

persistent.gap: You don't understand vertical spring-mass systems.
persistent.action: Three energies: GPE + KE + Es = constant. At equilibrium: mg = kx, v = max.

kinetic_energy.title: Understanding Kinetic Energy
kinetic_energy.instructions: Complete the statements about kinetic energy.

sentences.text: Kinetic energy is the energy associated with {{d1}}. The formula is KE = {{d2}}, and it is a {{d3}} quantity.

d1.tooltip: What does kinetic energy depend on?

d2.tooltip: Remember the ½ and the squared velocity.

sentences.text: Kinetic energy is proportional to velocity {{d4}}. This means if velocity doubles, KE becomes {{d5}} times greater.

d4.tooltip: KE = ½mv². What power of v?

sentences.text: The SI unit of kinetic energy is the {{d6}}, the same as all forms of energy. KE is always {{d7}} or zero.

gravitational_pe.title: Understanding Gravitational Potential Energy
gravitational_pe.instructions: Complete the statements about gravitational potential energy.

sentences.text: Gravitational potential energy (GPE) is energy stored due to an object's {{d1}} in a gravitational field. The formula is GPE = {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: GPE depends on position in the field.

sentences.text: GPE is measured relative to a {{d3}} point where GPE = 0. Only {{d4}} in GPE have physical significance.

d3.tooltip: Where is GPE defined as zero?

sentences.text: In the formula GPE = mgh, g represents the {{d5}} with value {{d6}} m/s² near Earth's surface.

d6.tooltip: Standard value for g near Earth.

elastic_pe.title: Understanding Elastic Potential Energy
elastic_pe.instructions: Complete the statements about springs and elastic potential energy.

sentences.text: Hooke's law states that the force exerted by an ideal spring is F = {{d1}}, where k is the {{d2}} with units {{d3}}.

d2.tooltip: k measures the stiffness of the spring.

sentences.text: Elastic potential energy stored in a spring is Es = {{d4}}. This formula comes from the {{d5}} under a force-extension graph.

d5.tooltip: Area = ½ × base × height for triangle.

sentences.text: A stiffer spring has a {{d6}} value of k. On a force-extension graph, the spring constant is the {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: Stiffer = more force per unit extension.

conservation.title: Conservation of Energy
conservation.instructions: Complete the statements about energy conservation and dissipation.

sentences.text: The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be {{d1}} or {{d2}}; it can only be transformed between forms.
In a closed system: KE + GPE + Es = {{d3}}. This means total {{d4}} energy is conserved.
In real systems, energy is dissipated to the environment as {{d5}}, {{d6}}, and deformation of materials.

kinetic_energy.title: Applying Kinetic Energy Concepts
kinetic_energy.instructions: Apply your understanding of kinetic energy.

sentences.text: A 2 kg ball moving at 5 m/s has KE = ½ × 2 × 5² = {{d1}} J. If it speeds up to 10 m/s, KE = {{d2}} J.

d2.tooltip: KE = ½ × 2 × 100 = 100 J. Speed doubled, KE quadrupled.

sentences.text: A car's speed increases from 20 m/s to 40 m/s. Since velocity doubled, its kinetic energy increased by a factor of {{d3}}.
Two objects have the same KE. Object A has mass 4 kg and Object B has mass 1 kg. Object B must be moving {{d4}} as fast as Object A.

d4.tooltip: If m is 4× smaller, v must be 2× larger (because v is squared).

sentences.text: A 1500 kg car at 30 m/s has KE = ½ × 1500 × 30² = {{d5}} J. This equals {{d6}} kJ.

gravitational_pe.title: Applying GPE Concepts
gravitational_pe.instructions: Apply your understanding of gravitational potential energy.

sentences.text: A 5 kg object at height 10 m has GPE = 5 × 9.8 × 10 = {{d1}} J relative to the ground. At height 6 m, GPE = {{d2}} J.
The change in GPE when the object falls from 10 m to 6 m is ΔGPE = {{d3}} J. This energy transforms to {{d4}}.
GPE can also be calculated from the {{d5}} under a gravitational force-distance graph. For non-uniform fields, this method is {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: When g varies, can't use simple mgh.

elastic_pe.title: Applying Elastic PE Concepts
elastic_pe.instructions: Apply your understanding of springs and elastic potential energy.

sentences.text: A spring with k = 200 N/m is compressed 0.1 m. The force required is F = 200 × 0.1 = {{d1}} N. The energy stored is Es = ½ × 200 × 0.1² = {{d2}} J.
If the compression doubles to 0.2 m, the stored energy becomes {{d3}} J. Energy is proportional to x{{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Double x → 4× energy. Es = ½ × 200 × 0.04 = 4 J.

sentences.text: At equilibrium in a vertical spring-mass system, the spring force equals {{d5}}. Using mg = kx, we can find the {{d6}} at equilibrium.
A ball dropped from 20 m starts with GPE = mgh and KE = {{d1}}. Just before hitting ground, GPE = {{d2}} and all energy is KE.

d1.tooltip: Initially at rest, so no KE.

sentences.text: In an elastic collision, both momentum and {{d3}} are conserved. In an inelastic collision, momentum is conserved but KE is {{d4}}.
Energy dissipated in an inelastic collision appears as {{d5}}, sound, and material deformation. Total energy is still {{d6}}.

kinetic_energy.title: Mastering Kinetic Energy
kinetic_energy.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of kinetic energy.

sentences.text: The work-energy theorem connects work and KE: W_net = {{d1}}. Positive work {{d2}} an object's KE; negative work {{d3}} it.
A key insight: momentum (p = mv) is linear in v, but KE (= ½mv²) is {{d4}} in v. Two objects with equal momentum have {{d5}} KE if masses differ.

d5.tooltip: Same p = mv but different m means different v and different KE.

gravitational_pe.title: Mastering GPE
gravitational_pe.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of gravitational PE.

sentences.text: For an object in free fall (no air resistance): mgh_i + ½mv_i² = {{d1}}. This allows us to find speed at any height.

d1.tooltip: Total energy at start = total energy at end.

sentences.text: A ball thrown upward slows because KE transforms to {{d2}}. At maximum height, KE = {{d3}} and all energy is GPE.

d3.tooltip: At peak: momentarily stationary, v = 0, KE = 0.

sentences.text: Using ΔGPE = mgΔh assumes {{d4}} gravitational field. For large altitude changes, must use area under {{d5}} graph.

d5.tooltip: Area under F-r graph = work = ΔGPE.

elastic_pe.title: Mastering Elastic PE
elastic_pe.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of springs and elastic PE.

sentences.text: In a horizontal spring-mass system (no friction), energy oscillates between {{d1}} and {{d2}}. At maximum compression/extension, KE = {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: At turning points, mass momentarily stops.

sentences.text: In a vertical spring system, three energies transform: GPE, KE, and Es. At equilibrium position, {{d4}} is maximum because net force is {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: F_net = 0 at equilibrium, but max v (no acceleration, constant velocity).

d5.tooltip: mg = kx at equilibrium, so F_net = 0.

conservation.title: Mastering Energy Conservation
conservation.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of energy conservation and dissipation.

sentences.text: In a perfectly inelastic collision, objects stick together. This results in {{d1}} KE loss among all collision types, but {{d2}} is still conserved.
When a bouncing ball loses height each bounce, the 'lost' energy has transformed to {{d3}}. This demonstrates why {{d4}} motion is impossible.
Summary: Total energy is always {{d5}}. In closed systems, mechanical energy (KE + PE) is conserved. In open systems, mechanical energy {{d6}} due to dissipation.
To check if a collision is elastic: compare KE_before and KE_after. If {{d7}}, elastic. If KE_after < KE_before, {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: Elastic means KE is conserved (equal before and after).
